uh well simply put tailwind css is a utility-based css framework
and what this really means is that with tailwind we apply atomic style classes
so these are very small very focused classes usually revolving around a
single css property and what we do is we compile those together and we compose them to create
the look that we want one of the really big uh sort of selling
points i feel for tailwind css is that you pretty much never have to actually
write any css okay and that is a very interesting thing i'm
going to be doing about 40 minutes or so of code demos in this talk and i will make a promise to you now that you're
not going to see me write out a single css property in order to do it
the other thing about tailwind css is it makes it very very quick to actually build uis okay because you're not having
to jump between files going creating css over here and then html structure and markup over there
it's very quick to develop you can build your eyes very rapidly so let's have a look at what this looks

tex grey 800 that refers to the colour palette that's built into tauwin towing comes with a a good set of colors

so hopefully you can see already that tailwind when you're using towel in css classes it's quite easy to understand
once you've learned the the shortened names that tailwind has exactly what styles are being applied to
what html elements and you're not having to flip back and forth between two files to check this stuff out
so this can really add uh some uh efficiency benefits
now as i mentioned tailwind comes with a design system and it's completely configurable it's very easy to configure
okay we configure this using a javascript object
it's got a built-in sizing scale and this applies to all kinds of things related to start relate to size so
things like padding and margins and things like this they all use this sizing scale
by default it ships with a proportionate scale so this makes life quite easy as the developer to kind of figure out
sizing because say you start off with a size of four but you want something a lot bigger where you go to eight and
eight is double the size of four okay it sort of makes sense when you're using it
but this is all configurable and you can change this and if you say are working somewhere with a design team you can
work with the designers to actually configure tailwind to match your design system okay so that's and that's like i
said quite an easy thing to do as i said it's got a color palette built into it and this is what that color
palette i've got the example here with purple it ranges from 50 up to 900 with 900 being the darker
shade 50 being the lightest and tailwind also has this concept of
variants which essentially marked to match to pseudo classes in css okay so things like hover
effects or odd even row effects or responsive um sort of
break points and things like that they all map to variance in tailwind okay
so really what you can think of with towerwind is it's essentially like lego blocks that's the way i look at it okay
we just put the various blocks together to compose the look and feel that we want and if we don't like it any point we
just discard a block and change it for something different if you think about that card component i showed you if i
want that that uh card title bit that h5 that was in there to be a different color i just swap text gray 800 for text
blue 500 and very quickly i've changed the text color okay i don't have to go into a css
file find the right class find the right property add in the hex code and what have you
so at this point people who are relatively new to tailwind start to get concerned
chris isn't this inline styles and as you're as old enough as i am to
remember when these were used a lot inline styles are known to be evil and we shouldn't be using them and this
is a fair question i think at this point so let's just quickly address the limitations of inline styles
so inline styles are essentially magic numbers or magic strings however you want to look at it what this means is if i've got an h1 tag
on a page and i want to add a certain set of styles to it to make it big and bold and whatever whatever
i can do that with inline styles on that one page on that one element if i want it on another page on another
h1 tag i have to essentially copy and paste that same set of inline styles and i do that again and again for every page
on my site the problem is if i want to change this i've now got an issue because i've now
got to go back through every single page i have and manually change all of these inline styles okay so that's not great
the other issue with or another issue i should say with inline styles is that we can't do any of
the more interesting things like hover effects okay so if i want a nice effect when i mouse over a link
i can't do that with inline styles they're just not physically support they just can't physically support that
and finally if you have any interest in responsive design then with inline
styles you are well out of luck because they don't support that either okay so we can build our websites
but we can't take any advantage of that and make it look good on mobile and tablet uh and and desktop so these are
some pretty significant limitations that you have with inline styles but none of this is the case for
tailwind because tailwind is still using css classes okay so we've got all the benefits of css classes and what they
can do but like i said they're just very very focused pretty much always on a single css
property so that's a bit about uh tower wind
let's start talking a bit about how we can bring tower wind and blazer together and how we would actually
add tailwind into a blazer project so there's a couple of options here um i'm going to talk about um the first one
we'll just skip through relatively quickly and this is using tailwind virus cdn so tailwind offers a pre-built
version of its of its library through their cdm you can just add a
link to it like this in your head tag and you're off to the races you can just start putting in those utility classes
and starting your site however this is relatively limited
um we can't customize anything as i mentioned uh talwin has this kind of rich design system that you can
configure really easily but because this is a pre-built file on a cdm we can't actually manipulate that
now i will caveat this by saying that this is true of tailwind and version v2 okay tailwind v3 you are actually gonna
be able to customize this doing some really interesting stuff um again it wouldn't be something you want to use in production but at development time you
can you could configure this um from the cdn but it's not something that's possible right now
tailwind comes as well with the set of sensible defaults okay if all of the various defaults of taowin
were turned on by were turned on from the get-go uh it generates like a 20 meg plus css
file okay which is pretty massive to the point where if you load that into a browser it slows it down devtools gets slow it's not that great so a lot of
things are turned off by default sensible defaults okay and this means that we can't turn them
on again from the cdm because we don't have access to that configuration file
we also can't use third-party plug-ins okay tailwind has a plug-in model and there's plenty of plug-ins available for
it um third party and first party plugins in fact but again we can't access the configuration file so we
can't use them and also we can't remove any unused styles so one of the uh
another good feature of talwind is the fact that has this ability to uh purge all of the unused css from its uh final
css file okay and it does this by looking at all of the files that you use tailwind classes in and then only
including those classes in the final outputted file this means that tailwind css files are usually very very small in
the region of 10k the cdn version isn't huge it's like i
think 70 to 80k i think last time i checked okay so it's not ginormously massive but that is like seven or eight
times bigger than you get it if you built it locally um so compared to that it is a bit bigger
so the other option and the one that we're going to use throughout our demos today is the tailwind cli
so um one of the advantages of using the tauwin cli and the way i'm going to show you today is that you don't actually
have to go through the process of creating things like package.json files this isn't going to create a big node modules
folder locally either or anything like that all we're going to need is node installed the machine okay so we can get
access to a command called mpx with tailwind cli we also get access to
like the watch mode that it has and this does some hot reload so this will watch the files that we're using um and it
will automatically rebuild our final css file if it needs to if anything changes for whatever reason
the tailwind cli also has optimizations for tailwind's jit compiler now this is in preview mode in v2 we're going to be
using this today but it will be the default in v3 which is probably going to be released in a few in the next sort of
month or two potentially so it's definitely worth understanding this and also with the tao and cli we can
also use other post css plugins um tailwind itself is a post css plugin and
if you're not aware of what post css is because i appreciate you might not be it's a tool for transforming css into an
abstract syntax tree and that means you can then walk that tree you can manipulate it you can do whatever you want to do reorder things
create new uh branch whatever and then you can just write that back to a css string when you're done and tailwind
uses this extensively to create utility classes
